meanings.definition: To make noble or elevate in character or status.
meanings.sent1: The kind act of helping others can ennoble a person's soul.
meanings.sent2: The king wanted to ennoble the brave knight for his heroic deeds.
meanings.sent3: The funny play showed how a simple gesture can ennoble even the silliest characters.
meanings.sent4: The artist's brush strokes ennoble the canvas, turning it into a masterpiece.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's encouraging words ennoble the students, inspiring them to reach for their dreams.

meanings.definition: To confer a title of nobility upon.
meanings.sent1: The queen decided to ennoble the loyal servant with the title of 'Sir.'
meanings.sent2: In the ceremony, the king will ennoble the brave warrior as a knight.
meanings.sent3: The playful puppy seemed to ennoble itself by wearing a crown made of flowers.
meanings.sent4: The magical wand had the power to ennoble any commoner into a noble lord.
meanings.sent5: The ancient ritual was believed to ennoble the chosen one with eternal grace and honor.

meanings.sent1: The simple act of kindness can ennoble even the smallest gesture.
meanings.sent2: The grand ceremony was meant to ennoble the occasion and make it memorable.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cat tried to ennoble its actions by wearing a tiny top hat.
meanings.sent4: The golden sunlight seemed to ennoble the entire landscape, making it glow with beauty.
meanings.sent5: The wise words of the elder ennoble the young listeners, guiding them towards wisdom and virtue.
